ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Python, how does polling work (and fail), the chain of media - voter - polling - candidate - votes

I learned some introductory data science skills in Python, and I learned a good overview of how data science is used in political campaigns (messaging, what works and what doesn't, voter information available to campaigns and how they use it, etc).
We learned how to use Python to analyze and visualize election and campaign data.
Python, statistics

Python 
Data analysis
Data viz
Political campaigning
stats

Understood the use and importance of data science in strategizing for political campaigns. Also developed comfortability in using Python - I feel like I got a great understanding of what it's used for and how to use it.
introduction to coding in python, independent data cleaning and application of class concepts, basic modeling and statistics associated with campaign data
I learned a lot about Python and political campaigning theory.
Good grasp of Python.
I became comfortable using Python to conduct real-world data analysis. I also learned a fair amount about campaign tactics and strategy

I learned a lot about the US political system and Python! This class is a great way for students to learn the important data analysis package of Pandas in a pretty laid-back and supportive environment.

I had already taken YData at Yale; this course helped me hone the Python skills I had gained in that course for specific data science purposes, and taught me to code within the pandas software specifically. We learned general tenets of political data science that were probably useful (don't overfit, make sure your sample reflects the population).
political data analysis
I learned how to code in python and learned a lot about how campaigns use data science to help their candidates.
Basic python skills, insight into the job landscape for political data science.
This course gives a solid foundation in the skills needed for an entry-level data science internship or position in politics.
Introduction to python and basic American votin
I learned python and also more about campaigns, voting turnout, etc. I learned what goes into campaigning, tactics politicians used, and how to conduct experiments to turn out voters.
I learned more about the ways political campaigns work. I also learned a good amount of Python and can now do things like build models that predict outcomes and evaluate those models.

This course allowed me to gain a variety of knowledge, skills, and insight especially when it came to data and coding. Being able to do python in this class really exposed me to a new skill that I was not as strong at. I appreciate the way in which from lab 1 we were able to start with the basics and then move on to more challenging work. In this class, I was also able to learn a lot more about the behind the scenes of the data used in politics.
Introductory to intermediate level statistics and coding in Python, as well as practical applications in politics.

- I learned the basics of Python
- I have a brief overview of how political campaigns and interest groups use data
- I learned how to evaluate the usefulness of experiments
- I can better recognize flaws in statistical experiments, and I know what questions to ask to evaluate it better

- python
-data analysis
-understanding of how campaigns use data
This class sharpened my knowledge about how political campaigns use data to target voters. It also greatly improved my knowledge of the Python language.
The many applications of data science towards political campaigns and elections in America
I learned the basics of coding and data analysis in Pandas. I learned the ways that voters voting and the role of political scientists during campaigns as far as turning out voters.
This was the best class Ive taken at Yale for practical skills. The final was like a test youd take to get a job. You learn how to evaluate models, display data, and code in Pandas. Also other stuff.
I learned the foundamentals of python and how to use it to analyze data

I learned much through the lecture content as well as the weekly labs (PSETs) code. The lecture content provided much insight into political campaigns and their tactics with regards to voters, among many other related subjects. My understanding of creating models, evaluating models, and interpreting models improved. Also, working through the weekly labs improved my skills in Python.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths: well-designed labs that train non-coders step-by-step
Weaknesses: Class contents on voting and polling were a little bit light, less intellectually challenging, and less thought provoking
Professor Kalla is great, he's very engaging and approachable. The workload is low and the psets are interesting and fun. Can't think of a way to improve the course.

For someone with very limited coding experience, I found this class very accessible. The labs build up your knowledge of Python gradually (and do rise a bit in difficulty towards the end of the semester), but they always felt doable. I do not recall spending more than four hours on any given lab, and the TA/ULA team was extremely helpful whenever we had questions. I appreciated that Professor Kalla gave us time at the end of class to work on our labs, as this made getting our questions answered much easier. 

The content covered in class was also fairly straightforward, and very digestible. I appreciated that the scope of the class was not overwhelming (i.e. the class took a "less is more" approach). The assignments and final project also gave us plenty of room to explore topics of interest to us.
Labs were hard but manageable. Content was very interesting!

Great class!
Very good for people who don't know much about python and still interesting for more experienced python programmers
The professor is awesome, the Tis were great, and I liked the format of it.

Strengths: Prof Kalla is passionate and very knowledgeable about the subject, explains concepts extremely well and committed to each students' understanding (when asked to re-explain, would do so and ensure students understood conceptually not just how plug in etc). The topics in the class are selected intentionally (we were able to see real data sets of voters, real data from canvassing orgs etc, new articles and understanding analysis behind them) that it made it more interesting to learn the data science as well. The homeworks and problems we were assigned felt meaningful to work on!

Weakness: While I understood the philosophy of coding is learnt best through doing and we had time in class to ask questions, given the size of the class and also varying coding backgrounds of the students, it might've helpful to walk through an example together of a hard/moderate difficulty problem in class together. Some felt there was a slight disconnect between the coding based homework and largely conceptual nature of the lectures. Nonetheless, it was definitely doable especially with the availability of office hours.

Strengths: so many. The collaborative portion of each class makes it super approachable, even if you dont have a strong coding background. professor Kalla and the TFs were also very straightforward about the expectations. 
Weaknesses: we didnt get keys of the labs, so there is no way of checking your work besides your grade.

Very helpful professor and TFS. Even though we do not learn the coding in class the labs are well structured to help you learn. I found that having to figure out the coding myself helped be better understand what I was doing.

Lectures were interesting and relevant.

Strengths: prof was good, content was interesting
Weaknesses: none
The Python modules were extremely clear and I feel much more confident in my ability to analyze data in Python/Pandas after taking this class.

I wish the course had been way more specific  teaching us to grab, interpret, and display data for very particular cases and problems instead of broad conceptual work. We never learned anything at all mind-blowing  and data is such a pivotal part of politics today! I wish all of the exercises for homework had been taken from real life examples of data display and manipulation. This course was very manageable, but it never felt like the homework, readings, and lectures were synced, and I would rather have worked harder for more interesting content than skimmed the surface as we did.
great course!!

Strengths: Prompt help on lab work, no grading curve
Weaknesses: Not much time in class
Going over more coding concepts in class would strengthen the course

strengths are organization
weaknesses are little to no help for those with no coding background

I really enjoyed the lecture portion of the class, where Professor Kalla would talk about the theoretical concepts surrounding campaigning. The coding section of the class was very difficult for me and I would have liked more guidance in this area - I know that coding is very self-taught based, but as someone who learns by doing, it would have been helpful to walk through some examples at the beginning of the class.
The class was well-thought and immersive. I feel like I learned a lot in a short amount of time. I do wish there was more support when learning how to code but attending office hours really helped.

I think the biggest strength of this class was the connection to the real-world that we were able to make all the time. It made the content a lot easier to understand because we got to apply it to something that we understood.
A weakness in this class was not really going over the content in the lab before we started them. I feel like most labs we were left to figure out alone with the internet and I realized during the second midterm review that had we had a breakdown of every function before the lab, it would have been a lot easier.

Prof. Kalla is phenomenal and does a great job at introducing new topics at a digestible rate. I think we could've talked about coding a bit more during class; however, I like the structure of using the last bit of class to ask questions about the lab and work on it in class.

- great skills building
- perfect size
- good support/exam prep
- not much connection between lectures/readings and graded assignments

Strengths - this class will make you better at coding 
weaknesses - the labs don't seem as relevant to the course at the beginning of the semester.

Strengths: very well organized, succinct introduction to Python, very relevant and timely applications to elections
Weaknesses: not really any

The course was very well organized. Something that really irked me however was that the short essay was single-spaced. I hate writing assignments single-spaced if i doesnt include a word count. Its much more depressing. I liked how the class was split in two, one part for the lecture and the other part for coding. While the syllabus says half and half, its more like two-thirds lecture and one third coding. I also did not like how office hours was meant to only answer specific questions and not air sur and be with the TF or other students. I dont understand why that was discouraged.
I think that the labs were really helpful to look back on and build my understanding of python

The strengths of this course is that the class lectures are very clear, Professor Kalla is very thorough with his explanations and welcomes questions throughout class, and clearly tells the class what he expects us to know and understand for the midterms.  Another strength is that the second part of the class is for starting work on the weekly labs; this also allows for students to ask questions about the lab in person before working on the labs outside of class. 

One way that it could be improved is by having more office hour sessions before the lab is due.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes. Good for students who only want to learn Python for data analysis but not full-fledge coding also a good intro course to US politics for international students

If they don't know any data science skills and or they want to learn about the uses of data science in politics campaigns, absolutely. It's a niche subject for sure, so know what you're getting into. But while niche, it's not really the most intellectually challenging, so anybody can take it. 
Also, if you already have some Python skills, you won't learn a ton more than that, but for those that don't it's great.
Yes.

Absolutely! As a humanities person, this class was one of the most enjoyable STEM classes I've taken at Yale. The content covered in class was a nice mix of quantitive/qualitative analysis, and I found plenty of opportunities to explore topics and themes that were of relevance to my major. 

The work for the class was also very manageable. The workload labs were extremely reasonable, and grading was not harsh by any standard.  Professor Kalla and the TA/ULA team also did an amazing job of helping us prepare for the midterm.
Yes! if you want to learn basic python skills and statistics related to politics 100% take this course. Kalla was amazing!
Would recommend! Great way to learn about political campaigns and the use of data in political campaigns. Can also learn Python!
Absolutely. If you are a poli-sci/global student and want to learn coding in a friendly environment, definitely take this class.
Yes, primarily for the reasons of the strengths aforementioned! Especially if you're interested in political science, this is probably the best intro/elective class to take.
Absolutely! Anyone interested in learning Python and political science should absolutely take this course.
Yes! Great class for Political Science students in need of a QR. Not too easy but definitely doable, there are a lot of resources to help you succeed.

I would! You really get out of this course what you put into it. If you go in wanting to learn about data science and campaign strategy, you can learn a lot - but I do know people who didn't put in as much effort and then weren't satisfied with the results. It's a pretty chill class, so if you're into the subject matter you should definitely consider taking it.

Yes, for sure. Anyone interested in social sciences and looking to go into industry should take this class. It's exceptionally well taught, and you'll learn some super useful data analysis skills that should prove super useful in future jobs and internships.

This course was an incredibly easy QR credit (though to be fair I was familiar with Python after having taken YData the previous semester). The material is objectively relevant to politics today, and wasn't dull exactly, but even having never studied Polisci in college I could basically have told you everything we learned before we learned it. I thought that the general YData class helped me to learn Python and apply it to fascinating and particular coding problems really quickly in a really fun way, and YData for political science was just never as exciting.
yes, its and awesome course and Professor Kalla is great
Yes! Really great way to engage with data in the political science major
If you have the time to dedicate to the labs, yes. You'll come away with valuable skills.
if you want a basic introduction to python class
I would if someone is eager to learn how to code. Coding was very difficult for me but I also learned a lot about campaigning, and Professor Kalla is very nice and engaging.
I would if the student wants to know more Python and more about U.S. political campaigns.
Yes! This class is a straightforward yet engaging way to work on your statistics and coding skills in a fun environment with low workload.

Yes! It's a good introduction to python especially if you've never used the language before. The grading is fair. The instruction is accessible. I liked the format of the final project because you could really dive into whatever interest you have.

If you have a desire to become better at coding and python while simultaneously learning more about the effect of Big Data, then this class is for you. Students have wide creative range for creative projects, and there is always help available if you need it. Put the effort into this class and you will be rewarded.
Absolutely! It may not be as interesting for you if you're not already very interested/knowledgeable about politics and elections though.
I would recommend it if you are interested in the content matter. Its not a simple QR to take so I would be invested in the topics being covered.

Yes! This is a great class, super useful and interesting. The lectures are interesting and the psets can be challenging, especially in the second half, but theyre not too bad, especially if youve done coding before. If you havent it might be tough. Professor Kalla is a great teacher though, and you really feel like youre learning real skills.
Yes! I think that Python was taught in a way that was easy to understand and look back on to utilize.

Just go to class, the midterms will be totally fine as long as you just go to class. When midterm 1 came around there were people I had never seen before in the room and they started to stick around after midterm 1 grades were posted.

Yes! This course taught by Professor Kalla is great. You not only improve coding skills, but you also learn a lot of insights about political campaigns. The professor is very understanding and the weekly PSETs are interesting.
